About Me

Let me tell you a few things...

BIO

Hello, world! My name is Jaimie. I am 30 years old, and for the past 4 - 5 years I have been living in China and teaching English to kindergarten aged students. I love my job, and my life in China. But I don't see either as a permanent situation. So! I decided to teach myself to code in the hopes of changing careers when I move back to Scotland in the near future. At this point in time, I have been working on learning HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Sass and Bootstrap. I've used a whole combination of courses and resources. My plan is to join the CodeClan bootcamp for Software Development when I return to Scotland, but in the meantime I will try my best to learn what I can on my own while blogging about it all here.

#100DaysOfCode

My Experience Of The 100 Days Of Code Twitter Challenge

When I first decided to start using my spare time to learn how to code, I was completely unaware of the wide array of topics and paths I could follow. I didn’t know what I was doing, or where I should begin.

I did a quick Google search and decided to start with Python, for no other reason than the name stuck out to me. I didn’t know what I could or couldn’t do with Python, or why it would be useful to me. But I jumped in anyway. As you can imagine, it didn’t take long for me to be overwhelmed and confused.

I was new to Twitter at the time, and after searching for the hashtag ‘#Python’ I then stumbled across #100DaysOfCode. It was a really exciting find for me. Not only did I learn a lot that day about the power of Twitter, I had also stumbled across an entire community of people in a similar situation to me, as well as lots of very experienced and super helpful people like Brad Traversy & Wes Bos (and the rest!).

After reading through hundreds of tweets with this hashtag, I was able to find multiple resources and more suitable starting points (turns out, HTML is a much easier and more suitable place to start!)

I jumped in and began tweeting everyday. I learned HTML & CSS through multiple resources (SoloLearn, FreeCodeCamp, CodeAcademy, Udemy Courses, and lots of YouTube tutorials). I followed a lot of people who were posting regular #100DaysOfCode updates and kept track of where they were at, and compared my own journey to theirs.

I moved on to learning Javascript and continued posting everyday.

Around 1 month in, I started to feel pressured by the hashtag. I found myself starting to focus more on making sure I had an interesting project to post about than actually learning as much as I could from every project. At that point I realised it was becoming detrimental for me, so I decided to take a break from posting and continued studying on my own. In fact, I deleted my Twitter entirely at that point. I believe it was around day 35.

A couple of months later, I felt more confident and attempted to restart my #100DaysOfCode with a new Twitter account. I found some of the same people I’d been communicating with the first time round and tried to rebuild my little community. It was around this time that the Corona Virus took hold in China, and my life was essentially turned upside down. I struggled with focus and motivation for a while, and missed quite a lot of my daily posts.

I felt a little embarrassed to start posting again from where I left off, and was reluctant to restart it again for the 3rd time! So, I’m now taking a new approach.

I study and code everyday for at least an hour, but usually more if I can. At the end of each day I write a diary entry on Evernote, similar to what I would have posted on Twitter, but for only my eyes. I feel I can be more real this way, and I don’t feel the pressure of making sure I’m doing something that will get likes.

I still visit Twitter and read what everyone else is up to, but I’m not currently contributing - I’m taking a much more private and personal route for now, but still hope (and plan) to start making posts again in the near future.
